alttext: Facsimile made in 1818 of a lost original of Herrad of Landsberg, Hortus Deliciarum
description: Detail from an illustration in the Hortus deliciarum, the first encyclopedia written by a woman. The author is Herrad of Landsberg, abbess of Hohenberg. The manuscript was made around 1180 and kept in the Bibliothèque municipale of Strassbourg. It was destroyed in a fire in 1870, but several copies of the illustrations were made in the course of the 19th century. This reproduction was made in 1818.

Paris, BnF, lat. 11127, f. 49r (detail): Different terms are used to introduce the interlinear gloss. These include abbreviations for ‘scilicet’ (‘s’) and ‘id est’ (‘i’), both meaning ‘that is’ and offering explanations of Boethius’ wording.

Paris, BnF, lat. 11127, f. 49r (detail): Different terms are used to introduce the interlinear gloss. These include abbreviations for ‘scilicet’ (‘s’) and ‘id est’ (‘i’), both meaning ‘that is’ and offering explanations of Boethius’ wording.
Paris, BnF, lat. 11127, f. 49r (detail): Here the word ‘exemplum’, ‘example’, has been added above the word ‘dico’, ‘I say’, in the text, indicating that Boethius is about to introduce an example.
Paris, BnF, lat. 11127, f. 49r (detail): Keywords are used summarise main points of the text.
Paris, BnF, lat. 11127, f. 49r (detail): Here a later reader has noted that the second book of the text starts here.
Paris, BnF, lat. 11127, f. 49r (detail): The gloss in this case is a correction, supplying text missed by the scribe.

Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 11r (detail): ‘Rara est adeo concordia formae atque pudicitiae’: ‘Beauty rarely coincides with chastity’ (Juvenal, Satires, 10.295) – gloss to De inventione I.XXIV.35, where Cicero notes that a person could be either handsome or ugly.

Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 41v (detail): ‘Facilius est commendare paupertatem quam sustinere’: ‘It is easier to praise poverty than to put up with it’. The quotation is attributed to ‘Seneca’ and paraphrases Seneca the Elder’s Controversiae II.18. The passage glosses the question of appropriate reward for virtuous acts (De inventione, II.XXXIX.115)

Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 70r (detail): ‘Nichil est iniquius his qui nusquam putant esse subtilitatem nisi ubi nihil est praeter subtilitatem’: ‘Nothing is more unfair than to think that acuteness is only present when there is nothing present but acuteness’. Quoting again from Seneca the Elder (Controversiae, I.21, trans. Winterbottom, LCL 463, p. 21), the quotation glosses Rhetorica ad Herennium II.XI.16, which concerns the dangers of ambiguous oratory.

description: Selfportrait of ‘Frater Rufillus’ in a 12th-century manuscript from (possibly) Weissenau, who depicts himself decorating the manuscript. Cologny, Fondation Martin Bodmer, Cod. Bodmer 127, f. 244r (detail).

Ramon Llull was also a frequent user of the library of Sorbonne. In 1311 he donated a copy of his works to the library and requested that it would be chained to the bookcase; a common but not so subtle way of preventing a book from being stolen.

the illustrator has moved the hook from Dialectic’s right hand (where Martianus placed it) to her left. Perhaps he considered it impossible to hold wax tablets ánd a hook in one hand.

alttext: Brussels, KB 5169, fol. 42r copyright Brussels, Koninklijke Bibliotheek, Special Collections
description: Brussels, KB, Ms. 5169, fol. 42r: In this ninth-century manuscript of Prosper of Aquitaine’s chronicle, snakes in the margin warn the reader that a heretic is about to enter the narrative. The use of this symbol points to a close association between serpents and heretics.

alttext: Facsimile made in 1818 of a lost original of Herrad of Landsberg, Hortus Deliciarum
description: Detail from an illustration in the Hortus deliciarum, the first encyclopedia written by a woman. The author is Herrad of Landsberg, abbess of Hohenberg. The manuscript was made around 1180 and kept in the Bibliothèque municipale of Strassbourg. It was destroyed in a fire in 1870, but several copies of the illustrations were made in the course of the 19th century. This reproduction was made in 1818.

Valenciennes, BM, Ms. 320 (304), f. 138r (detail): Thomas of Cantimpré, De natura rerum, De scorpione: “According to Solinus, the scorpion is a serpent with a friendly face like a maiden but has a poisonous sting in Its knotty tail”.

West door, Cathedral of Chartres, c. 1150. The throne of wisdom, framed by the liberal arts. The complex iconographical program is believed to have been designed by the scholar Thierry of Chartres, chancellor of the cathedral school from 1141 to c. 1155. Famous twelfth-century scholars such as William of Conches and Gilbert of Poitiers studied in Chartres.
Below each art is a famous practictioner. Dialectica is seated above (or supported by) Aristotle
Aristotle is depicted as the architect of thought
Dialectica from close up. the creature she is holding is according to some scholars a serpent, according to others a scorpion
Sculpture of Lady Dialectica next to Lady Grammar. Porch of the Münster of Freiburg in Breisgau, 13th century

alttext: Lyon, BM 244, f. 69v Paris, s. 13 ¾
description: Lyon, BM, Ms. 244 (176) (Paris, ca 1250-1275), f. 69v: Dialectica looks positively saintly in this illustration. She holds a fleur de lis, symbol of the virgin Mary. This meek damsel is a far cry from the dangerous lady depicted by Martianus and Alanus
Christ as a warrior, treading on the beasts. Mosaic in the Archbishop’s Chapel Ravenna, sixth century

Typus Logice, woodcut 1517. Logica (dialectic) is depicted as a huntress. With her two dogs, veritas and falsitas, she pursues the hare problema in the wood of opinions. Gregor Reisch, Margarita Philosophica Encyclopedia of the liberal arts Basel, 1517

Paris, BnF, lat. 1572 (Acts of the Council of Ephese, manuscript made in the 8th century in Tours), f. 78v-79r: The letters s (scribe) and d (dimitte) in the right margin are in the hand of Alcuin or his assistant. They indicate what should be copied and what not in his dossier against Felix.
Virtues battling for the soul of men, Prudentius, Psychomachia. Cambridge, Corpus Christi College ms 23, f. 18r. First half of the eleventh century

Saint Dominic and the Albigenses (1480). A painting by Pedro Berruguete (c. 1450-1504) depicting Dominic, founder of the Inquisition, checking books for heresy with a trial by fire.

Cambrai, BM, MS 620 (572), f. 1r (detail). The author, Giovanni di Andrea (c 1270-1348), in his study, surrounded by books in chests, bookcases and on his desk. A special carousel (a wooden wheel on which multiple books could be laid out) allows him to consult multiple books at a time. Depicted in a manuscript made c. 1340-1345 in Bologna.
Paris, BnF, Fr. 12584 (Roman de Renart, manuscript made in North-East France, c.1300-1350), f. 61r (detail): Peculiar pointing hands
Saint-Omer, BASO, Ms. 118, f. 1v: Manuscript with works of of Richard of St. Victor, made in North France in the first third of the 13th century.

Paris, BnF, Lat. 15350, f. 1r (detail): Here is a detail from a manuscript with quodlibetical disputations from, among others, Thomas Aquinas. The structure of the disputation is clear, with three questions (‘tria sunt quesita’, and further division of these into subquestions with ‘utrum’ (‘whether’).
Lyon, BM, MS 128 (060), f. 2r: Rhetorical manual from the 15th century, with Rhetorica ad Herennium and, among others, an ars praedicandi.

description: Cologny, Fondation Martin Bodmer, Cod. Bodmer 188, f. 10r (detail; the blue circles are added by us): manuscript from the thirteenth century with the Dragmaticon of William of Conches. In this image Logica is a part of Philosophia, and Dialectica is a part of Logica.

Paris, BnF, lat. 6638, f. 6bis r

In this example, the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’, is placed at the top left of the square. It’s placed alongside the other universal, but negative, proposition: ‘no men are just.’ At the bottom of the square we find the particular affirmative and particular negative propositions: ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’

The diagonal lines crossing the centre of the diagram (labelled ‘contradictoriae’) connect propositions which are contradictory to each other. For example, if ‘all men are just’ (the universal affirmative proposition) then ‘some men are not just’ (the particular negative proposition) is a contradictory statement. If ‘all men are just’ then the statement ‘some men are not just’ cannot be true. Similarly, reading across the other diagonal, if ‘no men are just’ then the proposition ‘some men are just’ cannot be true.’

The placement of the universal affirmative and negative propositions at the top of the square and the particular affirmative and negative propositions at the bottom is also meaningful; these are described as being ‘contrary’ to each other. That is, it is not possible for both of the universal propositions – ‘all men are just’ and ‘all men are not just’ – to be true, although they could be both false. However, while it is possible for both particular propositions – ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’ – to be true, they cannot both be false.

Finally, reading alongside the side of the square, a further relationship between the propositions, that of subalternation, is identified. If the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’ (placed at the top of the square), is true, then the corresponding particular affirmative proposition, ‘some men are just’ (placed at the bottom of the square), must also be true. Similarly, if the universal negative proposition, ‘no man is just’, then the particular negative proposition, ‘some man is not just’, must also be true.’
